utterances: Somebody will not hijack planes, but sabotage the control system of airports like JFK or - just imagine what can happen.
This is the case of cyberterrorism.

Yaakov Lappin, a national security reporter for the Jerusalem Post and author of ""Virtual Caliphate: Exposing the Islamist State on the Internet,"" says that Israeli officials are concerned about exactly those types of attacks.

He points to the recent targets of the hackers â the El Al airlines website, the Israeli stock exchange and credit cards - and asks what would happen if they took down the websites of emergency services or health care.

If you look at the fact that Hamas issued a statement this week saying that this is a new form of resistance, and they've jumped on the bandwagon, that in itself is going to act as a recruiting call for hackers across the Arab world to join in this constant attacks on Israeli websites.
For now, he adds, the attacks are limited to a small group of hackers.
But he says the jump from cybercrime to cyberterrorism is short.
For NPR News, I'm Sheera Frenkel.
The Arab League has announced a deal with Syria.
It's meant to end nearly eight months of violence there.
And Syrian state television says Bashar al-Assad's government has accepted the plan.
NPR's Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson reports now from Cairo, where the deal was announced.
(Foreign language spoken)
At a televised news conference at Arab League headquarters here, Qatar's Foreign Minister Sheikh Hamad bin Jassim al-Thani stressed that Syria's acceptance of the group's plan was not enough.
He urged Syrian officials to immediately implement the plan.
It calls on the government to withdraw tanks and armored personnel carriers from Syrian streets, release political prisoners, and meet with Syrian opposition leaders in the next two weeks.
(Foreign language spoken)
Recalculating.
Turn left, then turn right.

Well, you know, one of the interesting side effects potentially of this, Robert, is that during the Republican Convention, it appeared to many in the media and others that John McCain was doing his level best not to be seen to be too close to the Bush White House, and yet here he is now in a situation where he will be very close to the president over the next 24 hours, presumably.
Well, yes and no. I mean, let's put this in context.
The context is, is that this country is in a deep, deep financial mess and that we only have one president at one time, and that just so happens to be George W.
Bush.
So, regardless of whether or not, you know, you want to distance yourself from him or not, he's still relevant - he, meaning George Bush - and you have to work with him in that context.
And so - and it's not only just John McCain working with George W.
Bush.
It's Nancy Pelosi.
It's Barack Obama.
Let's remember that Senator Obama is scheduled to meet with the president as well to discuss this bipartisan solution to this problem.
So, I guess, to be fair to this conversation, we really need to understand that the president is still relevant.
Although he's unpopular, he's still relevant in the context of trying to get us out of this financial mess.
Now, one of the things that I talked about with Ron Elving a few moments ago was the fact that yesterday, Obama and McCain both sounded very similar in their approaches to the bailout package.
There did not appear to be much difference between them.
Is there any of that, that is distinctive in your mind, Melissa?
Well, I think one thing that's distinctive is that John McCain does seem to be acting in this moment as though this economic crisis is a new crisis or an unforeseen one.
The kind of suspension of the campaign resounds like the suspension or the scaling back of the GOP convention when the hurricane was coming ashore on the Gulf Coast.
Obviously, you can't predict a hurricane more than a few days out, so it was an unpredictable event.
But in the context of this economic crisis, this is actually - the warning signs for this have been coming down the road for quite awhile.
In fact, News & Notes has been doing an incredibly good job over the past six or seven months really detailing the economic crisis as it is emerging.
And Barack Obama was saying this - has been saying this since the primary campaign, that we were in an economic crisis, and John McCain consistently was saying that we were not.
So, if there is a difference, I think the difference had to do within the sense of judgment about what was coming down the road.
Let ask you, Robert Traynham, as we bring the conversation to a close, what happens now?
What do you think that is the next best move for John McCain?
How long should he continue in this suspended mode before he gets back officially onto the campaign trail?

You know, I've got to tell you, Tony, regardless of when the House and the Senate and the White House come to an agreement, and because they will, I mean, there's no question about that they will come to an agreement sooner rather than later John McCain actually rhetorically has the upper hand on this, because he can then say, again, I put my country first, number one.
Number two, I actually suspended everything to fly back to Washington, D.C., because this was not only important to me, but it's also very important to the millions of Americans out there.

So, I think just from a drama standpoint and also from a rhetorical standpoint, he will have the upper hand on this and says, I actually practice what I preach, I put my self-interest aside for the best interests of the country.
Now, granted, some people will look at that and say, well, that was nothing but just for partisan sake.

But I've got to tell you, regardless of whether it's for partisan sake or not, to actually put your presidential campaign on hold and to stop all advertising and to stop campaigning as little or as much as he may have been scheduled to do today and tomorrow and the next day, he actually has done it, and you've got to give him at least credit for that.
All right.
We've got to stop right there.
Thank you very much, Robert and Melissa.
Thanks.
Thank you.
That was Robert Traynham - he is the D.C.
bureau chief for the Comcast Cable Network CN8 - and Melissa Harris Lacewell.
She is an associate professor of politics and African-American studies at Princeton University.
I'm Celeste Headlee in Lake County, Indiana.
When polls opened this morning at Brunswick Elementary School in Gary, there were already more than 100 people waiting in line to vote.
I want to vote.
Got to vote.
So you're making sure you're first in line?
Is that what...
I don't have to be first.
Just make sure I vote.
That's Patricia Tatum, who arrived before sunrise.
Elections officials in Lake County held up results for hours during the primary.
They said they weren't prepared for the high voter turnout, and 40 percent of the electronic machines didn't properly tally ballots.
But no one seems to be concerned that workers won't be able to handle the turnout this time.
Melanie Brown (ph) says her state is ready.
Indiana could handle their business.
You know, we might slack with some things, but we can handle the crowd and handle the election polls and all that.
So I'm not concerned at all.
It's not concern over problems that has brought these people out so early.
It's a fierce determination to vote without any delay.
This is the first time after 30-some years.
This is the first time I think we ever got up this early to come vote.
Sharon Buckingham (ph) says all of her family and friends are bound and determined to cast their vote today.
Oh, yes.
Everyone.
No matter how long the lines are?
No matter how long the lines are.
Everybody's planning on voting.
In fact, hundreds of thousands of Hoosiers waited for up to seven hours to cast votes before election day during the early voting period.
Frances Mew (ph) says, if voters waited then, they'll wait now.
My daughter stood in line for four hours Sunday after she had worked about eight hours.
It's just an important time in our lives.
Yes.
It's exciting.
Like, I'm surprised right now.
I'm kind of speechless right now, so...
When the pollworkers arrive, they have to shoulder their way through the crowd to get inside.
Andrew Batiste (ph) gets to work using yellow nylon rope and folding chairs to mark the line outside the school.
He says he's shocked at the size of the crowd.
No. No. This is very unusual.
Do you think people - I mean, if the lines get longer, that people are going to turn around and go home?
No.
No. They're going to wait.
That's why some of them come early, trying to beat the other people who thinking they coming early.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I asked voters if they were concerned about problems at polling stations and that this might end up as a contested election.
Kenneth Parker (ph) says no way.
They can't let that happen again.
It'll look too bad for the country.
So then they're trying to keep it straight, you know, this time.
Ann Cheatham (ph) and Lambert Jackson (ph) say no one is leaving this line.
Not this time.
We're making history today.
We'll be here.
I ain't going home.
And I ain't going to let these people go home.
If I've got to go buy some coffee, it don't even matter.
